p: Could you explain to me the concept of "ghost in the machine" by Gilbert Ryle? I started reading Arthur Koestler's book of the same name, but I just returned the copy to its place in the library. His writing style is engaging, especially when he criticizes other theoretical positions, but his own thesis ends up being very incoherent.
a: "Ghost in the machine" is a phrase coined by British philosopher Gilbert Ryle in his 1949 book "The Concept of Mind." It is a criticism of Cartesian dualism, the philosophical view proposed by René Descartes that posits a separation between the mind (or soul) and the body. According to Cartesian dualism, the mind is an immaterial entity that resides within the physical body, controlling it and interacting with it.

Ryle critiqued this idea, arguing that it leads to a category mistake. A category mistake occurs when someone mistakenly applies the attributes of one category to another category, resulting in an illogical or incoherent concept. In the case of Cartesian dualism, Ryle believed that the mind and body are not two separate entities, but rather two aspects of a single, unified being.

The "ghost in the machine" refers to the idea of the mind as a separate, non-material entity that somehow inhabits and controls the physical body. Ryle saw this as a flawed and misleading conception, arguing that mental processes are actually just a different way of describing bodily actions and behaviors. In other words, there is no "ghost" or immaterial mind separate from the body; instead, mental states and processes are intrinsically linked to physical actions and behaviors.

Arthur Koestler's book "The Ghost in the Machine," published in 1967, borrows its title from Ryle's phrase but explores different themes. Koestler's work is a critique of behaviorism and reductionist approaches to understanding the human mind. He argues that such approaches fail to take into account the complexity of the human psyche and the influence of individual consciousness on behavior. While Koestler's writing style may be engaging, his own thesis might come across as incoherent or difficult to follow, as it covers a wide range of topics and ideas.

It's important to note that the Turing Test is not a definitive measure of intelligence or consciousness, but rather a benchmark for evaluating the performance of artificial intelligence in the context of human-like communication. p: Please write a story in which a narrator travels to a futuristic Buenos Aires to find César Aira's latest novel. It is 2045 and, through an app, people are able to write anything just by thinking about it. The app is called "Aira" and has made the concept of authorship disappear. At one point, the narrator enters a bookstore and realizes that all the books have "Aira" as their author, no longer César Aira, but all those who have written literature using the app.
a: Title: The Disappearing Author

In the bustling city of Buenos Aires in 2045, the skyline shimmered with neon lights and holographic projections. Skyscrapers soared above the remnants of the old city, and the streets teemed with people, most of whom had their eyes locked onto their holo-displays as they moved through the city.

As a literary historian, I had long been fascinated by the works of César Aira, an Argentine author who had gained global fame in the early 21st century. I arrived in Buenos Aires with the hope of finding his latest novel, one that was rumored to be his most groundbreaking work yet.

Walking through the city, I couldn't help but notice the ubiquitous advertisements for the new app called "Aira." The app, named in honor of the famed author, allowed people to write anything just by thinking about it. This technological marvel had revolutionized the literary world, but it had also led to the disappearance of the very concept of authorship.

Eager to find Aira's latest novel, I ventured into a dusty, old bookstore tucked away in a quiet corner of the city. The warm, musty smell of paper greeted me as I stepped inside, a stark contrast to the cold, sterile air outside. I marveled at the shelves lined with physical books, a rarity in this digital age.

I asked the shopkeeper for Aira's latest work, and he pointed me toward a section dedicated to the author. As I approached the shelves, I noticed that all the books had "Aira" as their author, but not César Aira. Instead, the books were authored by countless individuals who had used the app to create their own literary masterpieces.

Confused and somewhat disheartened, I picked up a random book from the shelf and began to read. The prose was beautifully crafted, the imagery vivid and the narrative engaging. It was a remarkable work of literature, but it lacked the distinctive voice that I had come to associate with César Aira.

As I continued to read, it dawned on me that the app had not only democratized the process of writing but had also stripped it of its uniqueness. In a world where anyone could create literature at the speed of thought, the concept of authorship had become obsolete.

I left the bookstore empty-handed, realizing that my search for Aira's latest novel was futile. I walked through the bustling streets of Buenos Aires, pondering the implications of a world without authors. The brilliant works of César Aira and countless other literary giants now seemed like distant memories, overshadowed by the unending stream of "Aira" novels.

Despite the technological marvels that surrounded me, I couldn't help but feel a sense of loss. In a world where literature could be created with such ease, I wondered if the true essence of the written word was at risk of being forgotten.

p: I already wrote that story, this is my version, could you perform a comparative analysis of both? We were going slowly. We had to slide slowly and orderly down the corridor, like a row of cows on their way to the slaughterhouse, because the fact was the same for everyone: a one-way trip. The pace, so slow and forced, ended up flooding me with a tremendous uneasiness. At one point I saw a young man who could not stand it any longer and ran past us, in the opposite direction. The signs said it: running away leads nowhere. In order not to despair, I thought again about the character of ideas. They do not seem to me to be made of words. From my point of view, they have a mineral trait: they are a kind of diamond that appears in the loose soil of consciousness. They resist, therefore, before us, in a way similar to the way they produce fascination. I assumed that at some point we would arrive at a door, but we just kept walking down the corridor, which gave the impression of an endless airport terminal. The analogy was supported by our traveler's attire: suitcases, bags and jackets tucked under our arms. Talking was not forbidden, but no one did, imprisoned in their personal ritual as I suppose we all were. When people are at the limit of their strength, they don't say half a word. In front of me, a man who limped a little and forced me to slow down, was repeating a prayer. Behind me, a beautiful black woman walked with her eyes glued to the ceiling. I was distracted imagining what I would find on the other side. Beyond the scientific discoveries and advances, I wondered if, in the future, humanity would still be connected to its old ways. Would they receive us as we were promised? I was hungry, what would we eat? My hands clenched tightly around the handle of my suitcase, full of clothes, books and notebooks, because yes, I was the only one of my friends who still wrote by hand. But there was no door. The hallway knew how to cross us through time without alteration. Suddenly, without stopping walking in a straight line, we returned to the point where we had entered. An assistant similar to the one who greeted us at the office, whose name may have been Liliana or Luciana, depending on her badge, was now helping us out into the city. Before long, I was alone. Buenos Aires was not much different from how I remembered it. At least the buildings of its belle époque were still intact, even though billboards of an aquatic material floated next to the palaces. One could enter them with one's eyes. Apparently, a fragment of the liquid, evaporated, condenses in your own thoughts and asks for your social card number. With that you can now access the products. Unfortunately, I only had a visitor's passport, which lasted a week. Then I had to get to work. On the street, people moved forward with a mixture of apathy and parsimony. Some things just didn't work, but no one seemed to care. When I tried to cross the street, the traffic light immediately changed color. We all moved back to our sidewalk while, in front of us, the automatic cars, "autotransits" they call them, accelerated in rows distributed in perfect symmetry. A boy tugged at my jacket. I looked at him: his left eye was missing. He stretched out his hand, I thought to ask, but then I saw a small and very cute hamster appear in it. I wanted to touch him, but the light turned green again and the boy vanished into the crowd. I entered the first restaurant I saw. It was a famous pizzeria, opened in 1932 and maintained since then with the same aesthetics. I took a seat on the second floor. The waiters were automated, one ordered while conversing directly from his table with the little holographic head projected in front of him. Then, rather quickly, an old man who seemed to have spent his entire life in that booth brought my pizza overflowing with mozzarella, silverware, napkins and a pitcher of Coke. I poured myself some booze and had dinner looking out the window at a bunch of bluebirds that I didn't know if they were parrots, a hologram or an introduced species. Although I don't quite remember who I was before the temporal crossover, my purposes retain their former thrust. I live, thus, thrown into what I do; I follow a thought without origin and it is kind. I was chewing the last piece of muzza when I saw it. The poster that earlier showed a poster of clothes and another of an immersive movie, announced, in furious pink and yellow letters: "La monja asesina, la última novela de César Aira" (The killer nun, the last novel by César Aira). I almost choked. I asked a human waiter passing nearby: -Excuse me, friend, what year is it? -2045. -Impossible. -Whatever. As I watched him walk away laden with trays, I wondered how he hadn't died. He must be, I thought. The sign showed him looking exactly as I remembered him: a warm smile, a distant, angular gaze, barely any gray hair. As I left the restaurant, I noticed that the bookstores on that street were still in place. I went into the first one, which sold a lot of old books, and asked the clerk for Aira's latest book. She started moving her eyes in an erratic way, as if looking for something I couldn't see. Then she walked to the exact location of a shelf and returned with a green-covered book. It read, "Complot of the Unnecessary Rabbits." -Excuse me, but this is not The Killer Nun. -You told me the last one, didn't you? -Of course I did. -It's this one. -I just saw on a poster that... -This one came in this morning. The cover showed the foliage of a night forest, full of white rabbit heads. I looked for the publication date and assumed it was that same day. -The saleswoman offered me a copy of The Killer Nun, identical to the one I had seen on the poster. I checked the publication date: the day before the other novel. Scratching my upper back, I asked the woman where the section with Aira's books was. She looked at me as if she didn't understand. -The section? -she insisted in a nasal voice. Then, for the first time, I looked carefully at the bookstore. On the shelf to my right, the spines bore only the title of each book, without a name. There was no need. When I pulled out any one, they all answered to the same patronymic. I began to take out books in desperation, one after the other, and they all came back to me, sometimes with a photo, sometimes without, to the smiling face on the poster. He was the author. And, in a way, everything was simpler. Later I found out that yes, Aira had died, but not before transferring his writing to a very fast Machine Learning software. It was called: Aira. According to what the saleswoman explained to me, this made it possible for anyone to write a book. Aira was all of us, after all. By dissolving authorship, we only gained in communion. With mild enthusiasm, the woman showed me the work she was working on. It was an account of her sleepless hours, written in those trances. -It doesn't take away my insomnia, but it makes it more entertaining. "I write by thinking," he added later, and showed me how it worked: two headphones are enough to connect to a huge network. In there, everything is much simpler. Writing something, for example. You just have to think about it and it's done. With some pride, the woman showed me some of her Aira favorites: the novel about a hunchbacked boy who learns to fly; another about Juanita, a Brazilian girl who goes from childhood to maturity; and a third where, after a failed scientific experiment, bees become the dominant species on Earth. All of them could have been written by her or by anyone else. It didn't matter. Puzzled, I left the store with four books in a bag. The wind seemed to have gone mad. I put an arm in front of my face and walked with my eyes half-closed, in the direction of the cold cosmopolis.

a: A good literary description has several characteristics that help bring a scene, character, or object to life for readers. These characteristics include:

Sensory details: Effective descriptions engage the reader's senses (sight, sound, touch, taste, and smell) to create a vivid, immersive experience. By incorporating sensory details, you help readers imagine and connect with the story.
Specificity: Be specific and concrete in your descriptions, using precise words and phrases to paint a clear picture. Avoid vague, generic descriptions that fail to evoke a strong image or emotion.

Relevance: Make sure the descriptions you include are relevant to the story and contribute to the overall narrative. Avoid unnecessary or excessive descriptions that can slow down the pacing or distract from the central themes.

Show, don't tell: Rather than explicitly telling readers what a character is feeling or what the atmosphere is like, use descriptions to convey these elements indirectly. For example, describe a character's actions, facial expressions, or body language to hint at their emotions.

Figurative language: Utilize similes, metaphors, and other forms of figurative language to create vivid, imaginative descriptions. These literary devices can add depth and meaning to your descriptions, making them more memorable and impactful.

Variety: Vary your sentence structure and word choice to create a more engaging and dynamic reading experience. Mix short and long sentences, and use a diverse vocabulary to keep your descriptions fresh and interesting.

Consistency: Ensure that your descriptions are consistent with the overall tone, style, and setting of your story. This helps to maintain a cohesive narrative and keep readers immersed in your fictional world.

Economy of words: While it's important to provide enough detail to paint a vivid picture, be mindful not to overdo it. Aim for concise, impactful descriptions that convey the necessary information without overwhelming the reader.
By incorporating these characteristics into your writing, you can create effective literary descriptions that engage readers and bring your story to life.

Economy of words: While these authors may not adhere to traditional notions of brevity, they still carefully choose their words and phrases to create a specific effect or convey a particular meaning.

In essence, writers like Faulkner, Beckett, and Bernhard push the boundaries of traditional description guidelines to create their unique and memorable styles. Philosophy: In philosophy, abstraction is the process of extracting general ideas or concepts from specific instances or experiences. Mathematics: Abstraction in mathematics involves representing a concept or structure in a general, simplified form that captures its essential properties without including unnecessary details. This process helps to make mathematical ideas more manageable, allowing us to work with complex concepts more efficiently.

Computer Science: In computer science, abstraction is a technique for managing complexity by hiding or encapsulating lower-level details of a system or process, enabling users or programmers to focus on higher-level concepts. This approach allows for more efficient problem-solving and improved maintainability of code.

Cognitive Psychology: Cognitive abstraction refers to the mental process of generalizing or categorizing information based on shared features or characteristics. This process helps us to organize and make sense of the vast amount of information we encounter in our daily lives.
